questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the pterion. 

The pterion is an H-shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

  1. Frontal bone
  2. Squamous part of the temporal bone
  3. Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  4. Parietal bone

It is located approximately 4 cm above the midpoint of the zygomatic arch. 

 

Centre of pterion is referred to as sylvian point and the bone is thinnest at this point.

Frontal branch of middle meningeal artery, vein and lateral sulcus of brain are situated immediately below this point. Pterion is one of the commonest site of fracture and leads to extradural hemorrhage because of injury to middle meningeal artery.

The pterion overlies the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and the lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere. The bone in this area is thin, and any injury to this area may lead to rupture of the middle meningeal artery, leading to extradural hematoma.

The pterion also corresponds to the site of the anterolateral (sphenoidal) fontanelle of the neonatal skull, which closes in the third month after birth.

Other options:

Option A: Asterion is the point where three cranial bones meet:

  • the parietal bone.
  • the occipital bone.
  • the mastoid portion of the temporal bone.

It lies 4 cm behind and 12 mm above the center of the entrance to the ear canal.

Option B: The glabella is the area of skin between the eyebrows and above the nose, that is slightly depressed, and joins the two brow ridges. 

Option D: The nasion (also known as bridge of the nose) is the midline bony depression between the eyes where the frontal and two nasal bones meet, just below the glabella.

questions.text: The following diagram shows the depth of respiration of a 55-year old man who was diagnosed with sepsis. Identify the pattern of breathing.
questions.solution:
The pattern of breathing seen in the image is Kussmaul’s Breathing. It is a type of deep, rapid breathing usually implies metabolic acidosis, but can also occur with Ponto-mesencephalic lesions.

Other options:

Options A and B: Biot's breathing - The pattern of breathing is irregular and rapid with rhythmical pauses lasting for 10–30 seconds. It is also known as ataxic breathing is associated with increased intracranial pressure and meningitis.

Options D: Cheyne-Stokes Breathing - Characterized by progressively deeper and sometimes faster breathing (crescendo-decrescendo cycles), with periods of apnea. It is seen in patients with heart failure and uremia.

questions.text: You are a biochemistry resident and perform the test for the reducing sugars during a lab demonstration. The outcomes of the test appear as shown in the image below. The reagent which you have used for this test contains all of the following contents except ____.
questions.solution:
The given test is Benedict's test, the Benedict's reagent used contains all the above contents except sodium hydroxide.

Benedict’s test is a test for reducing sugars. It is answered by all monosaccharides and most disaccharides except sucrose.

Principle: All monosaccharides and reducing disaccharides contain a free functional aldehyde or ketone group. When heated in the presence of an alkali, they are converted to enediols, which reduce the cupric compounds (Cu2+) present in Benedict's reagent to an insoluble precipitate of red cuprous oxide (Cu2O).

Composition of Benedict’s reagent:

  • Copper sulphate: Provides the source of cupric (Cu2+) ions
  • Sodium citrate: Complexes with cupric (Cu2+) ions to prevent its deterioration to cuprous ions spontaneously
  • Sodium carbonate: Provides an alkaline pH

Substances giving a positive reaction on Benedict’s test:

  • All monosaccharides such as glucose, galactose, fructose, pentoses
  • Reducing disaccharides such as lactose and maltose
  • Glucuronic acid, homogentisic acid, and ascorbic acid

Clinical correlate: Benedict's test is used to detect the presence of glucose in urine.

The color of the precipitate gives a rough idea about the amount of sugar present in urine. Hence, it is a semi-quantitative test.

Colour of the precipitate Amount of reducing sugar
Green 0.5%
Yellow 1%
Orange 1.5%
Red 2%

questions.text: When you are going through the case sheets of the patients admitted in your unit during your internship, you notice the following pedigree chart attached to one of the files. Which of the following diseases is the patient likely to have?
questions.solution:
The pedigree is representative of an autosomal dominant type of inheritance. Of the options mentioned, Huntington's disease shows an autosomal dominant pattern.

In the autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, both males and females are equally affected, and the affected individual has a 50% chance of passing it on to the offspring.

The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.

Other options:

Option B: Sickle cell anemia shows an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance
Option C: Hemophilia A shows an X linked recessive mode of inheritance
Option D:Rett syndrome shows an X linked dominant mode of inheritance.

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

 

Autosomal Dominant Disorders:

  • With every autosomal dominant disorder, some patients do not have affected parents. Such patients owe their disorder to new mutations involving either the egg or the sperm from which they were derived.
  • Clinical features can be modified by variations in penetrance and expressivity.
  • In many conditions, the age at onset is delayed, and symptoms and signs may not appear until adulthood (as in Huntington disease).

X-linked Recessive Conditions:

  • All sex-linked disorders are X-linked, and almost all are recessive.
  • Several genes are located in the “male-specific region of Y;” all these are related to spermatogenesis.
  • Males with mutations affecting the Y-linked genes are usually infertile, and hence, there is no Y-linked inheritance.
  • An affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons, but all daughters are carriers.
  • Sons of heterozygous women have, of course, a one-in-two chance of receiving the mutant gene.
  • Heterozygous females express the disorder partially because of random inactivation of one X chromosome.

Related Pearl: Autosomal Dominant Disorders

A Very Powerful DOMINANT Human

  • A: Achondroplasia
  • Very: von Willebrand disease
  • Powerful: Pseudohypoparathyroidism
    • D: Dystrophia myotonica
    • O: Osteogenesis imperfecta
    • M: Marfan syndrome
    • I: Intermittent porphyria
    • N: Neurofibromatosis
  • Adult polycystic kidney disease
    • N: Noonan syndrome
    • T: Tuberous sclerosis
  • Human: Hypercholesterolemia (Familial)
    • Huntington’s disease
    • Hereditary spherocytosis
    • Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy
    • Hereditary non-polyposis coli
    • Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital, with C/O seizures and the MRI image of the brain is given below. The disease is most probably caused by?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of seizures and the radiological findings of multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space, typical parenchymal brain calcifications are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by T. solium (Cysticercosis cellulosae).

Neurocysticercosis is the most common central nervous system parasitic infection.

The clinical features of neurocysticercosis include epilepsy, increased intracranial tension, hydrocephalus, psychiatric disturbances, meningoencephalitis, transient paresis, behavioral disorders aphasia, and visual disturbances.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presented with difficulty in urination, back pain, and an elevated PSA blood test. An X-ray revealed two radiolucent lesions in the bony pelvis and MRI revealed several enlarged lymph nodes in the lower abdomen. Which of the following drugs can most likely be used to treat the given condition?

PSA- Prostate-specific antigen
questions.solution:
The clinical features and investigations showing elevated PSA, osteolytic lesions and enlarged lymph nodes are suggestive of prostate cancer. Goserelin is a GnRH agonist used in the treatment of prostate cancer.

Androgen deprivation therapy is the primary medical therapy for prostate cancer. The drugs approved for this indication include leuprolide, goserelin, histrelin, buserelin, and triptorelin.

The agonist action of the GnRH analogs causes increased testosterone production, causing a tumor flare. It can be prevented by concomitant administration of an androgen receptor antagonist such as flutamide, bicalutamide, or nilutamide; until downregulation of testosterone is complete.

The combined androgen deprivation therapy with continuous GnRH agonist and an androgen receptor antagonist is as effective as surgical castration, in reducing the levels of serum testosterone and its effects. GnRH agonist can be used in the early and late course of the disease.

Other options:

Option a: Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor, used in the treatment of advanced breast cancer.

Option b: Desogestrel is a synthetic progestin without androgenic activity. It is used in combination with ethinyl estradiol for oral contraception.

Option c: Oxandrolone is a synthetic derivative of testosterone (anabolic steroid). It is used in the treatment of bone pain in patients with osteoporosis.

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a  history of ingestion of 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets.  Arterial blood gas revealed acidosis. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to iron toxicity, which is managed with deferoxamine (also known as desferrioxamine).

Large amounts of ferrous salts can be fatal in children. Initial symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal bleeding. In severe cases, cyanosis and hyperventilation due to metabolic acidosis can develop. This can sometimes be followed by an asymptomatic phase. Later, hypoglycemia and hepatic and renal failure can develop. Pyloric stenosis and gastric scarring can develop due to its corrosive nature. Ultimately, if left untreated, the child can die.

The gastric contents can be used for an iron color test to estimate the iron concentration in plasma. As iron tablets are radiopaque, an X-ray can be used to assess the number of pills taken. Deferoxamine, an iron chelator has to be administered intramuscularly. Side effects include pruritus, wheals, rash, and anaphylaxis. 

Deferiprone and deferasirox are other oral iron chelators used to treat iron overload in thalassemia patients. 

Other options:

Option B: Activated charcoal can be used in the initial management of acetaminophen and opioid overdose. It is used for gastrointestinal decontamination to prevent further absorption of the poison.

Option C: Dimercaprol, also known as BAL (British anti-Lewisite), is used to treat arsenic, mercury poisoning, and Wilson's disease.

Option D: D-penicillamine (Cuprimine) can be used to treat scleroderma, Wilson's disease, and rheumatoid arthritis. Side effects include nephrotoxicity, hematologic derangements, and a characteristic rash that involves the neck and axillae—elastosis perforans serpiginosa. It is associated with membranous glomerulonephritis, drug-induced lupus, and myasthenia gravis.

Related Pearl: Specific antidotes for poisoning

ANTIDOTE POISONING
4-methyl pyrazole Methanol and ethylene glycol
100% oxygen Carbon monoxide, cyanide, methemoglobinemia
Ammonium chloride Phencyclidine, amphetamine and strychnine
Amyl nitrate Cyanide, hydrogen sulphide
Atropine Carbamate and organophosphorus poisoning
Bupropion Nicotine
Calcium disodium edetate Cadmium, chromium, cobalt, copper, lead, magnesium, nickel, uranium, zinc
Calcium gluconate Precipitates fluorides, magnesium and oxalates
Chlorpromazine Amphetamine
Deferoxamine Iron, aluminium
Diazepam Amphetamine, chloroquine, alcohol withdrawal
Dicobalt edetate Cyanide
Dimercaprol (BAL) Antimony, arsenic, copper, lead, mercury, nickel and gold
Diphenhydramine Phenothiazines and related drugs
Disodium calcium edetate  Lead
DMPS *, (Unithiol)  Mercury
DMSA **  Lead
D-Penicillamine (Cuprimine) Copper, lead, mercury, chromate, nickel, zinc, arsenic
Ethanol Methanol and ethylene glycol
Fab fragment Digoxin, digitoxin, oleander tea
Flumazenil Benzodiazepine
Glucagon Propranolol and other beta-blockers toxicity
Hydroxocobalamin Cyanide
Labetalol hydrochloride Hypertensive crisis due to cocaine
Methionine Paracetamol
Methylene blue Methemoglobinaemia
N-acetylcysteine Paracetamol, acetaminophen toxicity
Nalorphine Morphine
Naloxone (Naltrexone) Narcotic, opiates, CNS depressants
Nicotinamide Vacor poisoning, phenylurea pesticide toxicity
Pancuronium bromide Neuromuscular blocking agents
Penicillamine Copper
Physostigmine salicylate Coma, convulsions from anticholinergics
Pralidoxime (2-PAM) Organophosphorus insecticides, nerve agents
Propranolol Cocaine intoxication, beta adrenergics
Protamine sulphate Heparin overdose
Prussian blue Thallium
Pyridoxine (Vit. B6) Isoniazid, hydrazine toxicity
Sodium bicarbonate Urinary alkalinisation for salicylates, phenobarbital
Sodium nitrite Cyanide
Sodium thiosulphate Cyanide
Vitamin K Warfarin

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess.

Peritonsillar abscess or quinsy is a collection of pus in the peritonsillar space which lies between the capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle. It usually follows an episode of acute tonsillitis when the crypta magna gets infected and gets sealed off. An intratonsillar abscess then forms which then bursts through the capsule to reach the peritonsillar space.

Usually, it is unilateral though occasionally bilateral abscesses are recorded.

It presents with marked odynophagia such that the patient cannot even swallow his saliva which dribbles from the angle of his mouth. The patient is usually dehydrated. Other features include a muffled and thick speech, often called a hot potato voice, sore throat, ipsilateral otalgia, torticollis, and fever.

On examination, the tonsil, pillars, and soft palate are congested and enlarged. The uvula is congested and oedematous and pushed to the opposite side. Mucopus covering the tonsil is seen. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes are enlarged and tender.

CECT, submandibular ultrasonography, and MRI are better suited for visualizing the abscess and its extent. Submandibular ultrasonography is also helpful for incision and drainage.

 Management of peritonsillar abscess:

  • Hospitalization
  • Intravenous fluids to address dehydration
  • High-dose intravenous antibiotics to cover aerobes and anaerobes
  • Analgesics for pain relief
  • Drainage by needle aspiration or incision and drainage
  • Tonsillectomy when there is airway obstruction or recurrence.

Incision and drainage of the abscess at the point of the maximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of the anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.

 Complications of peritonsillar abscess are:

  • Retropharyngeal abscess
  • Laryngeal edema
  • Parapharyngeal abscess
  • Septicemia
  • Pneumonitis/ lung abscess
  • Jugular vein thrombosis
  • Spontaneous hemorrhage from carotid artery/ jugular vein.

questions.text: The distance at which Jaeger’s chart is read is ______.
questions.solution:
Jaeger’s chart is held at a distance of 35 cm away from patient.

It is used to measure near vision.

The smallest letter is designated as N5 or J1 and the largest is N48.

Snellen's near vision chart can also be used.

questions.text: A 10 year old girl has just started menstruating. She will be provided with a pack of sanitary napkins by the ASHA in her village under:
questions.solution:
The girl will be provided with a pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rupees (called Freedays) by the ASHA under the Menstrual Hygiene Scheme which is a part of the Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK).

Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram:

  • Development of adolescent population (10-19 years).
  • Weekly Iron and Folic Acid supplementation (60mg Fe + 500 mcg Folic Acid)
  • Menstrual hygiene: A pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rupees (called Freedays) by the ASHA
  • It also includes enhancement of mental health and prevention of substance abuse and violence.

The LAQSHYA initiative is for improving the quality of labour rooms and providing Respectful Maternity Care. It also includes expanding the obstetric ICUs at government medical college hospitals.

The Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyaan (PMSMA) ensures quality antenatal care so that a pregnant woman receives at least 1 check up in her 2nd or 3rd trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic, on the 9th of every month.

Recent update: Department of Pharmaceuticals under ministry of Chemicals and Fertilizers has recently launched ‘Suvidha’ 100% Oxo-biodegradable Sanitary Napkin, under the Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Janaushadhi Pariyojana (PMBJP) on 28-05-2018 (World mentrual hygiene day). ‘Swachhta, Swasthya and Suvidha’ will be available for Rs.1 per pad over 3200 Janaushadhi Kendra for the underprivileged women of India.

questions.text: Which of the following steps is not included in the STEP approach of WHO?
questions.solution:
Therapeutic assessment is not included in the WHO's STEP approach. 

The STEP approach of WHO is a survey methodology developed to assess risk factors of non-communicable diseases(NCD). It helps countries establish an NCD surveillance system. The steps include the following:

  • Questionnaires contain questions about behavioral risk factors like tobacco use, alcohol use, diet, and physical activity. 
  • Physical measurements contain blood pressure, height, weight, and waist size
  • Biochemical measurements contain blood glucose, blood lipids, urinary sodium, and creatinine.  

Note: Mental health and suicide are included in optional behavioral risk factors (step 1). Hence, psychological assessment is also included in the STEP approach. 

Related Pearl: Sentinel Surveillance

  • Sentinel surveillance is used to augment the notification systems used in surveillance of diseases.
  • It detects the total case load and is used to identify the missing cases that are not notified among the old and new cases.
  • Sentinel data from the same is extrapolated to the entire population and the prevalence can be commented on.
  • Advantages: Bias in reporting is minimized and the feedback is simplified.

questions.text: What is the delivery criteria in a Type A PHC?

choices.text: It has more than 20 deliveries per month
It has less than 20 deliveries per month
It has more than 30 deliveries per month
It has less than 30 deliveries per month

questions.solution:
• Type A PHC has less than 20 deliveries per month.
  • Type B PHC has 20 or more deliveries per month.

Related Pearl: Primary Health Centres-PHC

  • One PHC per 30,000 population in plain areas and 20,000 in remote areas with a minimum of 6 beds.
  • Types:
    • Type A: PHC with less than 20 deliveries per month.
    • Type B: PHC with 20 or more deliveries per month.
  • Functions:
    • Medical care: OPD, emergencies, referrals and in-patient services.
    • Maternal and child health care, family planning and MTP
    • Health education
    • Nutrition services: malnutrition, vitamin A deficiency, anemia.
    • School and adolescent health services
    • Prevention and control of locally endemic diseases
    • Recording, collection, and reporting of vital events
    • Promotion of sanitation and testing of water
    • National health programme functions
    • Referral services
    • Training of health workers, ASHAs, ANMs, etc.
    • Basic laboratory services
    • Monitoring and supervising activities
    • Selected surgical procedures
    • Mainstreaming AYUSH and PMR

Indian Public Health Standard norms for manpower at PHC

Staff TYPE A TYPE B
Essential Desirable Essential Desirable
Medical Officer- MBBS 1   1 1#
Medical Officer -AYUSH   1~   1~
Accountant cum Data Entry Operator 1   1  
Pharmacist 1   1  
Pharmacist AYUSH   1   1
Nurse-mid wife (Staff-Nurse) 3 +1 4 +1
Health worker( Female) 1*   1*  
Health Assistantant (Male) 1   1  
Health Assistantant ( Female) Lady Health Visitor 1   1  
Health Educator   1   1
Laboratory Technician 1   1  
Cold Chain & vaccine Logistic Assistant   1   1
Multi-skilled Group D worker 2   2  
Sanitary worker cum watchman 1   1 +1
Total 13 18 14 21
*For Sub. Centre area of PHC
#If the delivery case load is 30 or more per month. One of the two medical officers (MBBS} should be female
~To provide choices to the people wherever an AYUSH public facility is not available in the near vicinity

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of sudden onset chest pain that radiates to the left arm and jaw. He is profusely sweating. An ECG was taken immediately. Interpret his ECG.
questions.solution:
The patient has a myocardial infarction (MI) with ECG changes of a left bundle-branch block (LBBB), which can be identified by the following classical features:

  • Wide QRS complex- QRS ≥120 ms 
  • Predominantly negative (QS) complexes in lead V1 and entirely positive (R) complexes in lead V6.
  • M pattern seen in left chest leads (V5, V6) 

MI can have the following ECG changes:

  • ST-segment elevation- zone of injury
  • T wave depression
  • Deep Q waves- late sign to develop
  • New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of LBBB: Mnemonic WILLIAM (W pattern in V1-V2; L-LBBB; M pattern in V3-V6)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of RBBB: Mnemonic MARROW (M pattern in V1-V2; R-RBBB; W pattern in V3-V6)

questions.text: The most common symptom of thyrotoxicosis is_____
questions.solution:
Hyperactivity and irritability are considered the most common symptoms of thyrotoxicosis.

Thyrotoxicosis means an excess of thyroid hormone in the body i.e increased T4 and T3.

Other symptoms of thyrotoxicosis include:

  •  heat intolerance and sweating, palpitations, fatigue, weight loss despite increased appetite, diarrhea, polyuria, and oligomenorrhea.

A few important signs suggestive of hyperthyroidism include:

  • tachycardia, tremor, atrial fibrillation in the elderly, goiter, muscle weakness, lid retraction or lag, signs of hyperdynamic circulation such as bounding pulse, wide pulse pressure, aortic systolic murmur.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of the ECG given below?
questions.solution:
The hallmark of this patient's ECG is the Osborn J wave.

Hypothermia is defined as core body temperature being less than 95°F.

In the initial stages of hypothermia, as a reaction to the general stress, there is sinus tachycardia. As the temperature drops below 90°F, there is sinus bradycardia associated with prolongation of the PR interval, QRS complex, and QT interval progressively.

With temperature approaching 86°F, atrial ectopic activity is often noted and can progress to atrial fibrillation. It is at this level of hypothermia that many patients have Osborn waves that consist of an extra deflection at the end of the QRS complex. J waves occur when a heterogeneous distribution of potassium current enhances the activity of a transient outward potassium current in the heart, caused by low temperatures.

Osborn waves, also known as J waves, camel-hump waves, or hypothermic waves, are best seen in the inferior and lateral precordial leads. They become more prominent as the body temperature drops, and they regress gradually with rewarming.

A progressive widening of the QRS complex occurs when the temperature falls below 86°F, which is associated with an increased risk of ventricular fibrillation and asystole occurs when the temperature drops to about 60°F.

Other options:

  • Hyperkalemia: Tall, tented T waves are seen in hyperkalemia.
  • Hypokalemia: U waves are seen in hypokalemia.
  • Hypocalcemia: Prolonged QTc interval, occasional T wave inversion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of sudden, involuntary, and uncontrollable dance-like movements. He also complains of facing difficulty with his memory. His wife says he has gotten very emotional recently.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of sudden, involuntary, and uncontrollable dance-like movements, along with cognitive and emotional symptoms, is characteristic of Huntington's disease (HD), also known as Huntington's chorea.

Huntington's disease (HD) is a degenerative disease of the caudate and putamen (“striate neurons”) caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the Huntington gene (chromosome 4), which results in motor, behavioral, oculomotor, and cognitive dysfunction. HD is characterized by rapid, nonpatterned, semi-purposeful, involuntary choreiform movements of limb, face, or trunk. A phenomenon referred to as anticipation is seen particularly in males, with subsequent generations having larger numbers of repeats and earlier ages of disease onset.

Tetrabenazine and deutetrabenazine are inhibitors of VMAT2 and cause presynaptic depletion of catecholamines. Deutetrabenazine is a newer form of tetrabenazine approved for the treatment of chorea associated with Huntington's disease. Deutetrabenazine takes advantage of the stronger bonds that deuterium forms with carbon (deuterated tetrabenazine). They have a longer half-life than the corresponding products of tetrabenazine metabolism.

Tetrabenazine is extensively metabolized by CYP2D6. It may cause hypotension and depression with suicidal tendencies. It can also cause Parkinsonism. Deutetrabenazine has adverse effects similar to those of tetrabenazine.

Other Options:

  • Parkinson's disease is characterized by tremors, bradykinesia (slow movement), and rigidity. It does not typically cause the dance-like choreiform movements seen in HD.
  • Friedreich ataxia is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the nervous system, causing progressive ataxia (loss of coordination). It does not typically present with choreiform movements.
  • Alzheimer's disease primarily affects memory and cognitive function, but it does not cause dance-like choreiform movements.

questions.text: Which of the following is the next step in the management of an old patient who has undergone complete excision of glioblastoma?
questions.solution:
Standard treatment post-surgical resection of glioblastoma includes radiotherapy in older patients. Radiation alone is effective as a single-modality therapy in the elderly owing to the survival benefit of radiation. Moreover, the combined-modality therapy of Chemoradiation has increased the risk of Neurotoxicity.

It is used in combination with temozolomide chemotherapy in younger individuals. Temozolomide is used as a first-line agent for the management of glioblastoma multiforme. It is used for newly diagnosed cases along with radiotherapy and also used for maintenance therapy. Bevacizumab, which is a vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) antibody may be used in the treatment of recurrent glioblastoma. 

Glioblastoma is the most common adult primary intracranial neoplasm. It affects people usually in the sixth or seventh decade. These tumors may arise de novo or may result from a malignant transformation of lower-grade astrocytomas. Mutations of Isocitrate Dehydrogenase (IDH) and Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor gene (EGFR) are implicated in the pathogenesis of the same. 

Clinically, patients usually present with headaches, seizures due to raised intracranial pressure or focal neurologic deficits depending upon the site involved. 

Grossly, glioblastomas are found infiltrating the brain tissue and are poorly delineated. They have greyish tumor cells with central yellowish necrosis and multiple areas of hemorrhages. Microscopically, they are composed of poorly differentiated pleomorphic astrocytic cells with nuclear atypia and high mitotic activity. Necrosis and florid microvascular proliferation are characteristic. They exhibit pseudopalisading—dense arrangement of tumor cells lining up around the foci of tumor necrosis.

According to the WHO Classification of CNS diseases 2016, glioblastomas are classified as follows:

  • Glioblastoma, IDH-wildtype:
    • About 90% of cases
    • Primary or de novo glioblastoma
    • Over 55 years of age
    • Worst prognosis
  • Glioblastoma, IDH-mutant:
    • About 10% of cases
    • Secondary glioblastoma, with a history of prior lower-grade diffuse glioma
    • Arises in younger patients
    • Poor prognosis
    • Glioblastoma, NOS (not otherwise specified), where full IDH evaluation cannot be performed.

The given histological image shows foci of necrosis with pseudo-palisading of malignant nuclei and endothelial cell proliferation, which are characteristic of glioblastoma (previously called glioblastoma multiforme).

questions.text: Perforation of the oesophagus is managed surgically in all cases except which of the following?
questions.solution:
Instrumental perforations in the cervical esophagus are usually small and can nearly always be managed conservatively.

Indications for considering nonoperative management in esophageal perforation:

  • Small septic load
  • Minimal cardiovascular upset
  • Confined to mediastinum
  • By flexible endoscope
  • Cervical esophagus

Indications for surgical exploration in esophageal perforation :

  • Large septic load
  • Septic shock
  • Pleura breached
  • Boerhaave’s syndrome
  • Perforation of the abdominal esophagus

Esophageal perforation:

  • Iatrogenic/spontaneous
  • Iatrogenic instrument-induced perforation is the most common cause of esophageal perforation.
  • Iatrogenic perforation is most common in cervical esophagus in the cricopharyngeal area.
  • Spontaneous perforation refers to Boerhaave’s syndrome.
  • Pain is the most common presentation of perforation.
  • Crepitus may be present.
  • Complications of esophageal perforation are pneumothorax and empyema (most common in the left side of the chest and bilateral in 10% of cases).
  • Hamman sign, mediastinal crunch is seen
  • Investigations:
    • X-ray chest
    • CT scan
    • Esophagogram
    • Thoracentesis
    • Serum amylase level may be raised.
  • Treatment: Primary closure within 24 hours of injury and conservative treatment in selected cases.

questions.text: Genetic testing for BRCA 1/BRCA 2 is indicated for all of the following except:

choices.text: Breast cancer diagnosed in a post menopausal female >50 years of age

questions.solution:
Genetic testing is not recommended in post-menopausal females >50 years of age. 

Genetic counselling is the process of discussing various genetic testing such as BRCA testing and multiple gene panel testing.

Genetic counselling and testing for genetic mutations (BRCA 1, BRCA 2 and others such as TP53, PTEN) are recommended for high-risk women with:

  • Breast cancer diagnosed before age 50
  • Triple-negative breast cancer
  • Bilateral breast cancer
  • Breast and ovarian cancer in the same individual
  • Breast cancer in men
  • Family history (maternal or paternal) of two or more individuals with breast and ovarian cancer
  • A close male relative with breast cancer
  • A close relative with early-onset (<50 years) breast or ovarian cancer
  • Known BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation in the family

 

Related Pearl: Risk factors and protective factors for breast carcinoma

Risk factors

  • Age: Incidence increases with increasing age.
  • Sex: more common in females.
  • Family history of breast cancer
  • Race, ethnicity (white women have increased risk compared to women of other races)
  • History of radiation exposure
  • Mammographically dense breast
  • Genetic factors:
  • Mutations in tumor suppressor genes
    • BRCA 1
    • BRCA 2
    • TP53
    • CHEK2
  • Hereditary syndromes
    • Li Fraumeni syndrome
    • Cowden’s syndrome
    • HNPCC syndrome
    • Peutz-Jegher’s syndrome
    • Ataxia telangiectasia
  • Hormonal factors (hyperestrogenemia is the risk factor)
    • Early menarche
    • Late menopause
    • First full-term pregnancy >30 years
    • Nulliparity
    • Obesity (postmenopausal)
  • Higher socioeconomic status, high fat diet, alcohol intake

 

Protective factors

  • Early age at first pregnancy
  • Multiparity
  • Breastfeeding
  • Oophorectomy
  • Exercise
  • Tamoxifen and Aromatase inhibitors

Related Pearl: Comparison between BRCA 1 and BRCA 2:

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes.

Carcinoma breast occurs at an earlier age and is bilateral and multicentric in inherited forms compared to sporadic cases.

  BRCA 1 BRCA 2
Location Long arm of chromosome 17  Long arm of chromosome 13
Differentiation Poorly differentiated Well-differentiated
Hormone receptor status ER/PR- Negative, Her-2 negative – triple negative ER/PR- Positive
Associated Cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, and prostate (lesser extent), Pancreas (lesser extent)  cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, prostate, pancreas, gall bladder, stomach cancers, and melanoma
Male breast carcinoma  Low association Increased risk
Fanconi’s anemia  Associated Associated
Medullary carcinoma Associated No association

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a 23-year-old man presents with breathlessness. On examination, he has hypotension and distended neck veins. On auscultation, muffled heart sounds are heard. What is this condition primarily associated with?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of Beck's triad (hypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds) is seen in cardiac tamponade. Shock due to cardiac tamponade is primarily an example of obstructive shock.

Obstructive shock is characterized by a reduction in preload due to mechanical obstruction of the cardiac filling of the left and/or right sides of the heart, which in turn leads to fall in cardiac output. Common causes of obstructive shock include:

  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Massive pulmonary embolus or air embolus

Cardiogenic shock is due to primary failure of the heart to pump blood. It may be due to myocardial depression as a result of infarction, cardiomyopathy, blunt myocardial injury. Patients with cardiac tamponade may eventually develop cardiogenic shock as the myocardium is stressed against the obstruction.

questions.text: Immediately post-delivery, the uterus corresponds to __ weeks of gestational age:
questions.solution:
Immediately post-delivery, the uterus corresponds to 20 weeks of gestational age.

The rate of involution of the uterus can be clinically assessed by noting the fundal height of the uterus in relation to the symphysis pubis.

Involution of the uterus occurs due to a decrease in the size of muscle fibers.

Time following delivery Features Weight of the uterus
Immediately following delivery 

Uterus corresponds to 20 weeks gestational age. Fundus lies just below the umbilicus

 1000 g
48 hours  Myometrial involution starts  -
1 week Rapid involution of uterus 500 g
2 weeks The uterus becomes a pelvic organ 300 g
4 weeks Clinically, involution is complete 100 g
6-8 weeks

Uterus returns to normal (pre-pregnant) size

Sonographically, involution is complete at 8 weeks

 60 g

questions.text: A young female patient is undergoing evaluation for infertility and is posted for a hysterosalpingogram. Which of the following is not a contraindication for hysterosalpingography?
questions.solution:
All of the following are contraindications for hysterosalpingography (HSG) except option C. Uterine synechiae is an indication for HSG.

Contraindications for HSG:

  • Presence of genital tract infection and bleeding
  • Genital Tuberculosis, due to the risk of spreading infection.
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Allergy to the dye
  • Premenstrual phase
    • If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged.
    • Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye, at the cornual end.
    • There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is an imaging technique used for visualization of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by the injection of a radiopaque dye. 

It is best performed between day 5 and day 10 of the menstrual cycle.

10-15ml of the dye is injected using a Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter. If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

It is used to detect:

  • Tubal patency
  • Uterine anomalies
  • Uterine polyps
  • Uterine synechiae
  • Feasibility of tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct

Surrogacy for treatment of infertility 

Vaginal hypoplasia is surgically corrected at the time of marriage

 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any   Uterine rupture, abortions, risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct Metroplasty (Resection of membrane and fundal recombination) Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation 
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part fused where as upper part unfused Metroplasty in selected cases  Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 

Diminished fertility, Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation

 
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (cockscomb cervix)   Ectopic pregnancy,  cervical incompetance,  clear cell adenocarcinoma of vagina and cervix 

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: Information obtained by lateral plate X-ray pelvimetry are all except ______
questions.solution:
The bispinous diameter can be viewed in the anteroposterior view and not the lateral plate X-ray pelvimetry.

For complete evaluation of the pelvis, three views are taken — anteroposterior, lateral and outlet. But X-ray pelvimetry is restricted only to the erect lateral view (the femoral head and acetabular margins must be superimposed) which gives most of the useful information.

Anteroposterior view can give the accurate measurement of the transverse diameter of the inlet and bispinous diameter.

questions.text: Which of the following milestones is expected to be seen in a child at 5 years of age?

choices.text: Riding a tricycle and making a tower of 9 blocks
Establishment of handedness and parallel play

questions.solution:
At the age of 5 years, a child is expected to dress and undress themselves.

Developmental milestones at the age of 5 years include:

  • Motor - skips
  • Adaptive - Draws a triangle
  • Language - Asks meaning of words
  • Social - Dresses and undresses

Undressing is easier and hence learned before dressing.

  • 2 years - Helps to undress
  • 3 years - Helps in dressing (if helped with buttons)
  • 5 years - Dress and undress fully (without any help)

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental Milestones
At 1 year
  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months
At 2 years
  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories
At 3 years
  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children
At 4 years
  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a gradually progressing swelling and pain for 6 months over the upper tibia. His radiographic image is shown below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiographic image findings are most suggestive of Brodie's abscess.

All of the given conditions may present with a history of swelling and pain. However, the differentiating features of each of the given conditions are as follows:

Condition Age group Radiographic findings
Brodie's abscess

Children, adolescents

 Lytic lesion with dense sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction
Osteosarcoma Children, adolescents and seventh decade Periosteal reaction leading to sunray appearance and Codman triangle
Osteoclastoma 20-40 years Lytic lesion with thin sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction
Ewing's sarcoma 10-20 years Periosteal reaction leading to onion peel appearance

questions.text: Which of the following does not suggest a medical cause of mental illness?
questions.solution:
Auditory hallucination is not suggestive of a medical cause of mental illness.

Hallucinations are perceptions in the absence of stimuli to account for them.

Auditory hallucinations are the hallucinations most commonly seen in the psychiatric setting. Nonauditory hallucinations often suggest that there is a neurologic, medical, or substance withdrawal issue rather than a primary psychiatric issue.

Features of the medical cause of mental illness:

  • Acute onset (within hours or minutes, with prevailing symptoms) First episode
  • Older age 
  • Current medical illness or injury
  • Significant substance abuse
  • Nonauditory disturbances of perception
  • Neurologic symptoms—loss of consciousness, seizures, head injury, change in headache pattern, change in vision
  • Classic mental status signs—diminished alertness, disorientation, memory impairment, impairment in concentration and attention, dyscalculia, concreteness
  • Other mental status signs—speech, movement, or gait disorders
  • Constructional apraxia—difficulties in drawing clocks, cubes, intersecting pentagons, Bender–Gestalt test

questions.text: The correct preoperative fasting recommendation is _________

choices.text: 2 hours for breast milk in infants

questions.solution:
The correct preoperative fasting recommendation is 2 hours for liquids in adults.

Recommended Preoperative Fasting period:

  • For neonates and infants:
    • 2 hours for clear fluids
    • 4 hours for breast milk
    • 6 hours for solids and infant formula
  • For all above 1 year of age:
    • 2 hours for clear fluids
    • 6 hours for a light meal
    • 8 hours if the meal contains fried, fatty food

Preoperative fasting is intended to reduce the risk of pulmonary aspiration.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a man with diffuse hair loss involving crown and frontal scalp with maintenance of frontal hair line?
questions.solution:
Female pattern baldness presents with diffuse thinning of hair over the mid‐frontal scalp with minimal or no bitemporal recession.Usually vertex baldness is absent and frontal hair line is maintained.

Male pattern baldness involves vertex baldness and frontal hair line recession.

Currently, the Hamilton-Norwood classification system for males and the Ludwig system for females are most commonly used to describe patterns of hair loss.

Ludwig system:

As the pattern of hair loss differs between men and women, the terms male pattern hair loss and female pattern hair loss are also used although the ‘male’ pattern may occur in women & vice versa

questions.text: The plain X-ray shows a particular pathological change in ribs and is seen in:
questions.solution:
The X-ray depicts the inferior rib notching which is one of the findings in coarctation of the aorta.

The most common location of coarctation of the aorta is just beyond the origin of the left subclavian artery.

  • Plain radiograph findings:
    • A figure of 3 sign (Reverse 3): Contour abnormality of the aorta
  • Inferior rib notching: Roesler sign
    • Secondary to dilated intercostal collateral vessels which form as a way to bypass the coarctation and supply the descending aorta
    • The dilated and tortuous vessels erode the inferior margins of the ribs, resulting in notching.
    • Not seen in infancy (unusual in patients <5 years of age)
    • Usually, the 4th to 8th ribs are involved, 1st and 2nd ribs do not become notched.

questions.text: Identify the heart chamber marked in the given CT image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above CT image is the left atrium.

Transverse CT images are to be observed from the foot end of the supine patient, as if we are sitting at the patient's feet. So the right-hand side of the observer corresponds to the left-hand side in the CT.
